This page serves as a quick reference for finding plugins for commonly used features. Feel free to request additional plugins to be listed here by submitting a request on the [Docs GitHub Repository](https://github.com/NativeScript/docs/issues/new?title=%5Brequest%5D%20add%20%60xyz%60%20to%20the%20recommended%20plugins&body=%3C!--%20Please%20fill%20this%20with%20more%20details,%20and%20make%20sure%20to%20update%20the%20issue%20title.%20--%3E).

## WebSockets [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#websockets)

### @valor/nativescript-websockets [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#valor-nativescript-websockets)

For web-compatible WebSockets, we recommend installing the [`@valor/nativescript-websockets`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@valor/nativescript-websockets) plugin:

NPMYarn

bash

```
npm i --save @valor/nativescript-websockets
```

bash

```
yarn add @valor/nativescript-websockets
```

## Image Caching [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#image-caching)

For image-heavy applications, it's a good practice to adopt an image-caching strategy that helps keep the memory usage down (remote images are cached after first download for example).

### @triniwiz/nativescript-image-cache-it [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#triniwiz-nativescript-image-cache-it)

One of the go-to plugins is [`@triniwiz/nativescript-image-cache-it`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@triniwiz/nativescript-image-cache-it). It uses `SDWebImage` on iOS and `Glide` on android.

NPMYarn

bash

```
npm i --save @triniwiz/nativescript-image-cache-it
```

bash

```
yarn add @triniwiz/nativescript-image-cache-it
```

### @nativescript-community/ui-image [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#nativescript-community-ui-image)

Another great plugin is from the NativeScript-Community ['@nativescript-community/ui-image'](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@nativescript-community/ui-image). It uses `SDWebImage` on iOS and `Fresco` on android.

NPMYarn

bash

```
npm i --save @nativescript-community/ui-image
```

bash

```
yarn add @nativescript-community/ui-image
```

## Text [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#text)

### @nativescript-community/ui-label [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#nativescript-community-ui-label)

As an alternative to the core [Label](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/label), check out [`@nativescript-community/ui-label`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@nativescript-community/ui-label).

NPMYarn

bash

```
npm i --save @nativescript-community/ui-label
```

bash

```
yarn add @nativescript-community/ui-label
```

## HTTP [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#http)

### @nativescript-community/https [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#nativescript-community-https)

A drop-in replacement for the core HTTP with improvements and additions like connection pooling, form data support and certificate pinning. Check out [`@nativescript-community/https`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@nativescript-community/https).

NPMYarn

bash

```
npm i --save @nativescript-community/https
```

bash

```
yarn add @nativescript-community/https
```

### @klippa/nativescript-http [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/recommended-plugins\#klippa-nativescript-http)

A drop-in replacement for the core HTTP with improvements and additions like connection pooling, form data support and certificate pinning. Check out [`@klippa/nativescript-http`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@klippa/nativescript-http).

NPMYarn

bash

```
npm i --save @klippa/nativescript-http
```

bash

```
yarn add @klippa/nativescript-http
```

Previous [‚ÜêPlugins](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/development-workflow/using-packages)

Next [Testing‚Üí](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/testing)

## Slider UI Component
[**üöÄ 8.9 Released!** ‚Üí ‚ö°Ô∏è New Node-API Engine Preview, üì≤ ns widget ios, üíÖ Tailwind v4 and more...\\
Read Announcement‚Üí](https://blog.nativescript.org/nativescript-8-9-announcement)

Menu

- [Docs](https://docs.nativescript.org/)

- [Snacks](https://docs.nativescript.org/snacks/)
- [Plugins](https://docs.nativescript.org/plugins/)
- [UI Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/)
- [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/)

- [Layout Containers](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#layout-containers)
  - [StackLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/stack-layout)

  - [WrapLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/wrap-layout)
  - [DockLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dock-layout)
  - [AbsoluteLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/absolute-layout)
- [Navigation Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#navigation-containers)
  - [Frame](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/frame)
  - [Page](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/page)
  - [ActionBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/action-bar)

  - [Alert](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#alert)

- [Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#components)

  - [Button](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/button)
  - [DatePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/date-picker)
  - [HtmlView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/html-view)
  - [Image](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/image)
  - [Label](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/label)
  - [ListPicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-picker)
  - [ListView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-view)
  - [Placeholder](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder)
  - [Progress](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress)
  - [ScrollView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/scroll-view)
  - [SearchBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/search-bar)
  - [SegmentedBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/segmented-bar)
  - [Slider](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider)
  - [Switch](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch)
  - [TabView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/tab-view)
  - [TextField](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-field)
  - [TextView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-view)
  - [TimePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/time-picker)
  - [WebView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/web-view)

`<Slider>` is a UI component that provides a slider control for picking values within a specified numeric range.

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Slider.ea3be06a.png)

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Slider.a74366f7.png)

TypeScript
TypeScript
Angular
Angular
Vue.js
Vue
Svelte
Svelte
Solid
Solid
React
React

xml

```
<Slider value="75" minValue="0" maxValue="100" />
```

html

```
<Slider value="75" minValue="0" maxValue="100" />
```

tsx

```
<slider value="{sliderValue}" onValueChange={sliderValueChanged} />
```

tsx

```
<slider
  width={300}
  value={sliderValue()}
  on:valueChange={handleChange}
/>
```

svelte

```
<slider bind:value={sliderValue} />
```

vue

```
<Slider v-model="sliderValue"/>
```

## Props [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#props)

### value [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#value)

ts

```
value: number
```

Gets or sets the currently selected value of the slider.

Defaults to `0`.

### minValue [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#minvalue)

ts

```
minValue: number
```

Gets or sets the minimum value of the slider.

### maxValue [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#maxvalue)

ts

```
maxValue: number
```

Gets or sets the maximum value of the slider.

### ...Inherited [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#inherited)

For additional inherited properties, refer to the [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/class/Slider).

## Events [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#events)

### valueChange [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#valuechange)

ts

```
on('valueChange', (args: PropertyChangeData) => {
  const slider = args.object as Slider
  console.log('Slider value changed to', args.value)
})
```

Emitted when the value of the slider changes.

See [PropertyChangeData](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/interface/PropertyChangeData).

## Native component [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider\#native-component)

- Android: [`android.widget.SeekBar`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/SeekBar.html)
- iOS: [`UISlider`](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uislider)

Previous [‚ÜêSegmentedBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/segmented-bar)

Next [Switch‚Üí](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch)

On this page

1. ‚Üë Top
2. [Props](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#props)
1. [value](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#value)
2. [minValue](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#minvalue)
3. [maxValue](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#maxvalue)
4. [...Inherited](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#inherited)
3. [Events](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#events)
1. [valueChange](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#valuechange)
4. [Native component](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider#native-component)

    - [Android](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/extending-classes-and-implementing-interfaces-android)
    - [iOS](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/extending-classes-and-conforming-to-protocols-ios)
  - [Create Custom Native Elements](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/create-custom-native-elements)
  - [Customizing View Elements](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/customizing-view-elements)
  - [Shared Element Transitions](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/shared-element-transitions)
  - [Multithreading](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading)
  - [Code Sharing](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/code-sharing)
  - [Metadata](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/metadata)
  - [Marshalling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/marshalling/)
    - [iOS Marshalling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/ios-marshalling)
    - [iOS Runtime Types](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/ios-runtime-types)
    - [Android Marshalling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/android-marshalling)
  - [Platform Version Handling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/platform-version-handling)
  - [Widgets for iOS](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/widgets-ios)

The `Color` class enables the creation of a color object:

- using color components (alpha, red, green, blue) ranging from 0 to 255,
- using various color representations like ARGB, color names, hex values, and more.

The `ios` and `android` properties of the `Color` class instance return the native platform instance of [UIColor](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uicolor) on iOS and [Color](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/Color) on Android.

## How to use the Color class [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#how-to-use-the-color-class)

### Create a color object from a hex value [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#create-a-color-object-from-a-hex-value)

ts

```
const color = new Color('#FF00CC')
const colorShortHex = new Color('#F0C')
```

### Create a color object from an alpha value [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#create-a-color-object-from-an-alpha-value)

ts

```
const colorARGB = new Color(100, 255, 100, 100)
```

## Color API [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#color-api)

The Color class offers the following properties and methods.

### constructor [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#constructor)

Creates a color object. The Color class offers the following constructor overloads:

ts

```
const color = new Color(knownColor)
```

Creates a Color instance from a known color name.

- `knownColor` : A color name string such as `'red'`, `'purple'`, `'orange'`.

ts

```
const color = new Color(hex)
```

Creates a Color instance from a color hexidecimal code.

- `hex`: A string of a hexidecimal color value such as `'#fff'` or `'#FF00CC'`.

ts

```
const color = new Color(argb)
```

Creates a Color instance from a number representing a color with an alpha.

- `argb`: A number such as `4293377432` as, representing color.

ts

```
const color = new Color(alpha: number, red: number, green:number, blue: number, type?: 'rgb' | 'hsl' | 'hsv')
```

* * *

### a [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#a)

ts

```
colorAlpha: number = color.a
```

Gets the Alpha component of the color. This is a `read-only` property.

* * *

### r [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#r)

ts

```
colorRed: number = color.r
```

Gets the Red component of the color. This is a `read-only` property.

* * *

### g [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#g)

ts

```
colorGreen: number = color.g
```

Gets the Green component of the color. This is a `read-only` property.

* * *

### b [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#b)

ts

```
colorBlue: number = color.b
```

Gets the Blue component of the color. This is a `read-only` property.

* * *

### argb [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#argb)

ts

```
colorARGB: number = color.argb
```

Gets the Argb Number representation of this color where each 8 bits represent a single color component. This is a `read-only` property.

* * *

### hex [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#hex)

ts

```
colorHex: string = color.hex
```

Gets the Hexadecimal string representation of the color.

* * *

### name [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#name)

ts

```
colorName: string = color.name
```

Gets the known name of this instance. Defined only if it has been constructed from a known color name - e.g. "red".

* * *

### android [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#android)

ts

```
androidColor = color.android
```

Gets the android-specific integer value representation. Same as the `ARGB` one.

* * *

### ios [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#ios)

ts

```
iOSColor: UIColor = color.ios
```

Gets the iOS-specific [UIColor](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uicolor) value representation.

* * *

### Color.equals() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#color-equals)

ts

```
areColorsEqual: boolean = Color.equals(value1: Color, value2: Color)
```

A static Color class method that compares two `Color` instances and returns `true` if they are the same or `false` otherwise.

* * *

### Color.isValid() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#color-isvalid)

ts

```
isValidColorValue: boolean = Color.isValid(value)
```

A static Color class method that validates if a value can be converted to a color.

* * *

### Color.fromIosColor() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#color-fromioscolor)

ts

```
colorFromIosColor: Color = Color.fromIosColor(value)
```

Creates a Color instance from iOS-specific UIColor value representation. `value` is of type [UIColor](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uicolor).

* * *

### Color.mix() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#color-mix)

ts

```
colorMix: Color = Color.mix(color1: Color, color2: Color, amount: number)
```

A static method that creates a Color instance from mixture of two colors.

* * *

### Color.fromHSL() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#color-fromhsl)

ts

```
colorNew: Color = Color.fromHSL(a, h, s, l)
```

A static method that returns a new Color from HSL.

* * *

### Color.fromHSV() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#color-fromhsv)

ts

```
colorNew: Color = Color.fromHSV(a, h, s, v)
```

A static method that returns a new Color from HSV.

* * *

### equals() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#equals)

ts

```
color.equals(value)
```

A Color instance method that checks whether the color instance on which the method is called equals the Color instance passed to the method.

* * *

### isDark() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#isdark)

ts

```
color.isDark()
```

A Color instance method that returns `true` if the color is dark or returns `false` otherwise. A color is dark when `brightenss < 128`.

* * *

### isLight() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#islight)

ts

```
color.isLight()
```

A Color instance method that returns `true` if the color is light or returns `false` otherwise.A color is light when `brightenss >= 128`

* * *

### getBrightness() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#getbrightness)

ts

```
colorBrightness: number = color.getBrightness()
```

Returns the color's [brightness](http://www.w3.org/TR/AERT#color-contrast) value.

* * *

### getLuminance [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#getluminance)

ts

```
colorLuminance: number = color.getLuminance()
```

Returns the color's [luminance](http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#relativeluminancedef) value.

* * *

### setAlpha() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#setalpha)

ts

```
colorWithAlpha: Color = color.setAlpha(a)
```

Adds the specified alpha to the color instance on which the method is called and returns the result as a new Color instance.

`a` is a value between `0` and `255`.

* * *

### toHsl() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#tohsl)

ts

```
colorHsl: { h: number; s: number; l: number; a: number } = color.toHsl()
```

Returns the hsl( `{ h: number; s: number; l: number; a: number }`) representation of the color.

* * *

### toHslString() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#tohslstring)

ts

```
colorHslString: string = color.toHslString()
```

Returns the [CSS hsl](https://www.w3schools.com/Css/css_colors_hsl.asp) representation of the color.

* * *

### toHsv() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#tohsv)

ts

```
colorHsv: { h: number; s: number; v: number; a: number } = color.toHsv()
```

Returns the hsv( `{ h: number; s: number; v: number; a: number }`) representation of the color

* * *

### toHsvString() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#tohsvstring)

ts

```
colorHsvString: string = color.toHsvString()
```

Returns the [CSS rgb](https://www.w3schools.com/Css/css_colors_rgb.asp) representation of the color.

* * *

### desaturate() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#desaturate)

ts

```
colorDesaturated: Color = color.desaturate(amount)
```

Desaturates the color by the specified amount. `amount` is a number between `0` and `100` inclusive. Providing `100` is the same as calling [greyscale](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color#greyscale).

* * *

### saturate() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#saturate)

ts

```
colorSaturated: Color = color.saturate(amount)
```

Saturates the color by the specified amount. `amount` is a number between `0` and `100` inclusive.

* * *

### greyscale() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#greyscale)

ts

```
colorGrayscaled: Color = color.greyscale()
```

Completely desaturates a color into greyscale. Same as calling [desaturate(100)](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color#desaturate).

* * *

### lighten() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#lighten)

ts

```
colorLightened: Color = color.lighten(amount)
```

Lightens the color by the specified amount. `amount` is a number between `0` and `100` inclusive. Providing `100` returns white.

* * *

### brighten() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#brighten)

ts

```
colorBrightened: Color = color.brighten(amount)
```

Brightens the color by the specified amount. `amount` is a number between `0` and `100` inclusive.

* * *

### darken() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#darken)

ts

```
colorDarkened: Color = color.darken(amount: number)
```

Darkens the color by the specified amount. `amount` is a number between `0` and `100` inclusive. `100` returns black.

* * *

### spin() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#spin)

ts

```
colorSpinned: Color = color.spin(amount)
```

Spins the hue by the given amount, from - `360` to `360`. Calling with `0`, `360`, or - `360` does nothing since it sets the hue back to what it was before.

* * *

### complement() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#complement)

ts

```
colorComplement: Color = color.complement()
```

Returns a Color instance that is the complement of the current color.

* * *

## Native Component [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/color\#native-component)

- `Android`: [android.graphics.Color](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/Color)
- `iOS`: [UIColor](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uicolor?language=objc)

  - [Code Sharing](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/code-sharing)
  - [Metadata](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/metadata)
  - [Marshalling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/marshalling/)
    - [iOS Marshalling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/ios-marshalling)
    - [iOS Runtime Types](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/ios-runtime-types)
    - [Android Marshalling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/android-marshalling)
  - [Platform Version Handling](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/platform-version-handling)
  - [Widgets for iOS](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/widgets-ios)

One of NativeScript's benefits is that it allows fast and efficient access to all native platform (Android/Objective-C) APIs through JavaScript, without using (de)serialization or reflection. JavaScript executes on the main thread (aka the UI thread). That means that operations that potentially take longer can lag the rendering of the UI and make the application lag.

To tackle issues with slowness where UI sharpness and high performance are critical, developers can use worker threads. Workers are scripts executing on a background thread in an absolutely isolated context. Tasks that could take long to execute should be offloaded to a worker thread.

The Workers API in NativeScript is loosely based on the [Web Workers API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Using_web_workers) and the [Web Workers Specification](https://www.w3.org/TR/workers/).

For optimal results when using the Workers API, follow these guidelines:

- Always make sure you close the worker threads, using the appropriate API ( `terminate()` or `close()`), when the worker's finished its job. If Worker instances become unreachable in the scope you are working in before you are able to terminate it, you will be able to close it only from inside the worker script itself by calling the `close()` function.
- Workers are not a general solution for all performance-related problems. Starting a Worker has an overhead of its own, and may sometimes be slower than processing a quick task. Optimize DB queries, or rethink complex application logic before resorting to workers.
- Since worker threads have access to the entire native SDK, the NativeScript developer must take care of all the synchronization when calling APIs which are not guaranteed to be thread-safe from more than one thread.

## Using Workers [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#using-workers)

### Spawning a worker [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#spawning-a-worker)

Creating a new worker is simple, all you need is to call the `Worker()` constructor with a path to the worker script (relative to current file, or an aliased path eg. `~/path/to/worker.ts`). The worker itself can be written in JavaScript or TypeScript.

ts

```
const myWorker = new Worker('./worker.ts')
```

### Sending messages to a worker [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#sending-messages-to-a-worker)

To send messages to the worker, use the [`postMessage()`](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#postmessage) method on the [`Worker`](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#constructor) instance.

ts

```
// send myMessage to the worker
myWorker.postMessage(myMessage)
```

### Receiving messages from a worker [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#receiving-messages-from-a-worker)

To receive messages from the worker, use the [`onmessage`](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#onmessage) callback on the [`Worker`](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#constructor) instance.

ts

```
// attach a message handler that will receive messages from the worker thread
myWorker.onmessage = (e) => {
  console.log('Message received from the worker thread.')
  const data = e.data // data from the worker
}
```

### Sending messages to main thread [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#sending-messages-to-main-thread)

To send messages back to the main thread use the [`self.postMessage()`](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#postmessage-1) method in the worker.

ts

```
// send the workerResult back to the main thread
self.postMessage(workerResult)
```

### Receiving messages from main thread [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#receiving-messages-from-main-thread)

To receive messages in the worker, use the [`self.onmessage`](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#onmessage-1) event handler in the worker.

ts

```
// attach a message handler that will receive the messages from the main thread
self.onmessage = (e) => {
  console.log('Message received from the main thread.')
  const data = e.data // data from myMessage
}
```

### Terminating a worker [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#terminating-a-worker)

If you need to stop executing the worker, you can terminate it from the main thread using the `terminate` method on the `Worker` instance:

ts

```
myWorker.terminate()
```

The worker thread is killed immediately.

### Handling errors [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#handling-errors)

Runtime errors inside the worker are reported back to the main thread through the `onerror` callback on the `Worker` instance.

ts

```
myWorker.onerror = (e) => {
  console.log(
    `Error occured in the worker thread in file ${e.filename} on line ${e.lineno}`,
  )
  console.log(e.message, e.stackTrace)
}
```

The worker can also self-handle errors by setting up an `onerror` handler, which can mark the error as "handled" and prevent the callback on the main thread from being called.

ts

```
self.onerror = (e) => {
  console.log('Error occured, error:', e)

  // return true-like to stop the event from being passed onto the main thread
  return true
}
```

## Workers API [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#workers-api)

### constructor [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#constructor)

ts

```
const myWorker = new Worker(path: string)
```

Creates an instance of a Worker and spawns a new OS thread, where the script pointed to by the `path` parameter is executed.

* * *

### postMessage [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#postmessage)

ts

```
myWorker.postMessage(message)
```

Sends a JSON-serializable message to the associated script's `onmessage` event handler.

* * *

### terminate [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#terminate)

ts

```
myWorker.terminate()
```

Terminates the execution of the worker thread on the next run loop tick.

* * *

### onmessage [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#onmessage)

ts

```
myWorker.onmessage = function handler(message: { data: any }) {}
```

Handles incoming messages sent from the associated worker thread. **Note** that you are responsible for creating & setting the handler function.

The `data` in the `message` object is the JSON-serializable message the worker sends with [postMessage](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#postmessage-1).

* * *

### onerror [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#onerror)

ts

```
myWorker.onerror = function handler(error: {
  message: string // the error message
  stackTrace?: string // the stack trace if applicable
  filename: string // the file where the uncaught error was thrown
  lineno: number // the line where the uncaught error was thrown
}) {}
```

Handles uncaught errors from the worker thread. **Note** that you are responsible for creating & setting the handler function.

* * *

## Worker Global Scope [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#worker-global-scope)

Each worker gets it's own global scope (so `global.foo` in the worker is not the same as `global.foo` on the main thread).

### self [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#self)

ts

```
self === global // true
```

Returns a reference to the `WorkerGlobalScope` itself - also available as `global`

* * *

### postMessage [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#postmessage-1)

ts

```
self.postMessage(message)
```

Sends a JSON-serializable message to the Worker instance's [`onmessage`](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#onmessage) event handler on the main thread.

* * *

### close [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#close)

ts

```
self.close()
```

Terminates the execution of the worker thread on the next run loop tick.

* * *

### onmessage [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#onmessage-1)

ts

```
self.onmessage = function handler(message: { data: any }) {}
```

Handles incoming messages sent from the main thread.

The `data` in the `message` object is the JSON-serializable message the main thread sends with [postMessage](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading#postmessage).

* * *

### onerror [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#onerror-1)

ts

```
self.onerror = function handler(error: Error): boolean {
  return true
}
```

Handles uncaught errors occurring during execution of functions inside the Worker Scope (worker thread).

If the handler returns a `true`-like value, the message will not propagate to the Worker instance's `onerror` handler on the main thread.

After `onerror` is called in the worker thread, execution is not terminated and the worker is still capable of sending/receiving messages.

* * *

### onclose [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#onclose)

ts

```
self.onclose = function handler() {
  // do cleanup work
}
```

Handles any "clean-up" work. Suitable for freeing up resources, closing streams and sockets.

* * *

## Example Worker [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#example-worker)

Note

In order to use `setTimeout`, `setInterval`, or other globals coming from the `@nativescript/core`, you will need to include them in your worker script:

ts

```
import '@nativescript/core/globals'
```

ts

```
// main-view-model.js

const worker = new Worker('./workers/image-processor')

// send a message to our worker
worker.postMessage({ src: imageSource, mode: 'scale', options: options })

// handle incoming messages from the worker
worker.onmessage = function (message) {
  if (message.data.success) {
    // the src received from the worker
    const src = message.data.src

    // terminate worker or send another message...
    worker.terminate()
  } else {
    // handle unsuccessful task
  }
}

// handle worker errors
worker.onerror = function (err) {
  console.log(
    `An unhandled error occurred in worker: ${err.filename}, line: ${err.lineno} :`,
    err.message,
  )
}
```

ts

```
// workers/image-processor.js

// load NativeScript globals in the worker thread
import '@nativescript/core/globals'

self.onmessage = function (message) {
  const src = message.data.src
  const mode = message.data.mode || 'noop'
  const options = message.data.options

  const result = processImage(src, mode, options)

  if (result) {
    // send the result back to the main thread
    self.postMessage({
      success: true,
      src: result,
    })

    return
  }

  // no result, send back an empty object for example
  self.postMessage({})
}

// example heavy function to process an image
function processImage(src, mode, options) {
  console.log(options)
  // image processing logic
  // save image, retrieve location
  // return source to processed image
  return updatedImgSrc
}
```

## Limitations [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/multithreading\#limitations)

There are certain limitations to keep in mind when working with workers:

- **No JavaScript memory sharing**. This means that you can't access a JavaScript value/object from both threads. You can only serialize the object, send it to the other thread and deserialize it there. This is what postMessage() function is responsible for. However, this is not the case with native objects. You can access a native object from more than one thread, without copying it, because the runtime will create a separate JavaScript wrapper object for each thread. Keep in mind that when you are using non-thread-safe native APIs and data you have to handle the synchronization part on your own. The runtime doesn't perform any locking or synchronization logic on native data access and API calls.
- **Only JSON-serializable objects can be sent with the `postMessage()` API**.
  - You can‚Äôt send native objects. This means that you can't send native objects with postMessage, because in most of the cases JSON serializing a JavaScript wrapper of a native object results in empty object literal - "{}". On the other side this message will be deserialized to a pure empty JavaScript object. Sending native object is something we want to support in the future.
  - Be careful when sending circular objects because their recursive nodes will be stripped on the serialization step.
- **No object transferring**. If you are a web developer you may be familiar with the ArrayBuffer and MessagePort transferring support in browsers. Currently, in NativeScript there is no such concept as object transferring.
- **Debugging workers is not currently possible.**
- **No nested workers support**. We want to hear from the community if this is something we need to support.

Previous [‚ÜêShared Element Transitions](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/shared-element-transitions)

Next [Code Sharing‚Üí](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/code-sharing)

## NativeScript Placeholder Component

- [Dialogs](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs)
  - [Alert](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#alert)

  - [Button](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/button)
  - [DatePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/date-picker)
  - [HtmlView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/html-view)
  - [Image](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/image)
  - [Label](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/label)
  - [ListPicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-picker)
  - [ListView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-view)
  - [Placeholder](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder)
  - [Progress](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress)
  - [ScrollView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/scroll-view)
  - [SearchBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/search-bar)
  - [SegmentedBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/segmented-bar)
  - [Slider](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider)
  - [Switch](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch)
  - [TabView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/tab-view)
  - [TextField](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-field)
  - [TextView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-view)
  - [TimePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/time-picker)
  - [WebView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/web-view)

`<Placeholder>` allows adding native views directly in your markup without creating a full [View](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder#) wrapper for it. When NativeScript is constructing the UI and encounters a Placeholder element, it emits a `creatingView` event, allowing you to pass in any native view to be rendered by assigning it to the `args.view` parameter.

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Placeholder.7d77856e.png)

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Placeholder.aa60cb68.png)

TypeScript
TypeScript
Angular
Angular
Vue.js
Vue
Svelte
Svelte
Solid
Solid
React
React

XMLTypeScript

xml

```
<Placeholder creatingView="creatingView" />
```

ts

```
import { Utils } from '@nativescript/core'

export function creatingView(args) {
  let nativeView
  if (__IOS__) {
    // Example with UITextView on iOS
    nativeView = UITextView.new()
    nativeView.text = 'Native View (iOS)'
  } else if (__ANDROID__) {
    // Example with TextView on Android
    nativeView = new android.widget.TextView(
      Utils.android.getApplicationContext()
    )
    nativeView.setText('Native View (Android)')
  }

  // assign it to args.view so NativeScript can place it into the UI
  args.view = nativeView
}
```

HTMLTypeScript

html

```
<Placeholder (creatingView)="creatingView($event)" />
```

ts

```
import { Component, NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA } from '@angular/core'
import { NativeScriptCommonModule } from '@nativescript/angular';
import { Utils } from '@nativescript/core'

@Component({
  selector: 'ns-placeholder',
  templateUrl: './component.html',
  imports: [NativeScriptCommonModule],
  schemas: [NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA]
})
export class PlaceholderComponent {

  creatingView(args) {
    let nativeView
    if (__IOS__) {
      // Example with UITextView on iOS
      nativeView = UITextView.new()
      nativeView.text = 'Native View (iOS)'
    } else if (__ANDROID__) {
      // Example with TextView on Android
      nativeView = new android.widget.TextView(
        Utils.android.getApplicationContext()
      )
      nativeView.setText('Native View (Android)')
    }

    // assign it to args.view so NativeScript can place it into the UI
    args.view = nativeView
  }
}
```

tsx

```
<placeholder onCreatingView={creatingView} />
```

tsx

```
<placeholder on:creatingView={creatingView}></placeholder>
```

svelte

```
<placeholder on:creatingView={creatingView}></placeholder>
```

vue

```
<Placeholder @creatingView="creatingView" />
```

## Props [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder\#props)

### ...Inherited [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder\#inherited)

For additional inherited properties, refer to the [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/class/Placeholder).

## Events [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder\#events)

### creatingView [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder\#creatingview)

ts

```
on('creatingView', (args: CreateViewEventData) => {
  const placeholder = args.object as Placeholder
  args.view = someNativeView
})
```

Emitted when building the UI, the event args allow passing a native view instance back via `args.view`.

See [CreateViewEventData](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/interface/CreateViewEventData)

### The story of üò¢ or üòä [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/best-practices/\#the-story-of-%F0%9F%98%A2-or-%F0%9F%98%8A)

We are providing a sample "vanilla" NativeScript app which shows some of the bad vs. good practices for you to run and see for yourself. Using vanilla NativeScript is a great way to see the raw examples of why these are bad and good practices which are applicable to any frontend framework integration. Each framework integration effectively utilizes these same practices for it's own various cases.

Clone and see for yourself: [https://github.com/NativeScript/examples-best-practices](https://github.com/NativeScript/examples-best-practices)

### [View bindings](https://docs.nativescript.org/best-practices/view-bindings) [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/best-practices/\#view-bindings)

### [Rogue timers and intervals](https://docs.nativescript.org/best-practices/rogue-timers) [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/best-practices/\#rogue-timers-and-intervals)

### [Various usages of @NativeClass() decorator](https://docs.nativescript.org/best-practices/native-class) [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/best-practices/\#various-usages-of-nativeclass-decorator)

## NativeScript Switch Component
[**üöÄ 8.9 Released!** ‚Üí ‚ö°Ô∏è New Node-API Engine Preview, üì≤ ns widget ios, üíÖ Tailwind v4 and more...\\
Read Announcement‚Üí](https://blog.nativescript.org/nativescript-8-9-announcement)

Menu

- [Docs](https://docs.nativescript.org/)
- [Tutorials](https://docs.nativescript.org/tutorials/)
- [Preview](https://preview.nativescript.org/)
- [Snacks](https://docs.nativescript.org/snacks/)
- [Plugins](https://docs.nativescript.org/plugins/)
- [UI Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/)
- [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/)

- [Layout Containers](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#layout-containers)
  - [StackLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/stack-layout)
  - [GridLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout)
  - [RootLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/root-layout)
  - [FlexboxLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/flexbox-layout)
  - [WrapLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/wrap-layout)
  - [DockLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dock-layout)
  - [AbsoluteLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/absolute-layout)
- [Navigation Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#navigation-containers)
  - [Frame](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/frame)
  - [Page](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/page)
  - [ActionBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/action-bar)

  - [Alert](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#alert)
  - [Action](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#action)
  - [Confirm](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#confirm)
  - [Prompt](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#prompt)
  - [Login](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#login)
- [Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#components)
  - [ActivityIndicator](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/activity-indicator)
  - [Button](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/button)
  - [DatePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/date-picker)
  - [HtmlView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/html-view)
  - [Image](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/image)
  - [Label](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/label)
  - [ListPicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-picker)
  - [ListView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-view)

  - [SearchBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/search-bar)
  - [SegmentedBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/segmented-bar)
  - [Slider](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider)
  - [Switch](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch)
  - [TabView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/tab-view)
  - [TextField](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-field)
  - [TextView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-view)
  - [TimePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/time-picker)
  - [WebView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/web-view)

`<Switch>` is a UI component that lets users toggle between two states.

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Switch.e3255ab6.png)

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Switch.795d39fc.png)

TypeScript
TypeScript
Angular
Angular
Vue.js
Vue
Svelte
Svelte
Solid
Solid
React
React

xml

```
<Switch checked="true" />
```

html

```
<Switch checked="true" />
```

tsx

```
<switch
  checked={switchValue}
  onCheckedChange={(args) => {
    setSwitchValue(args.value)
  }}
></switch>
```

tsx

```
<switch
  on:checkedChange={handleChange}
  checked={switchValue()}
></switch>
```

svelte

```
<switch bind:checked={switchValue}/>
```

vue

```
<Switch v-model="switchValue" />
```

## Examples [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#examples)

### Styling a Switch [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#styling-a-switch)

xml

```
<Switch checked="true"
  color="#BFCDAC"
  backgroundColor="green"
  offBackgroundColor="#DC493D"
/>
```

## Props [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#props)

### checked [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#checked)

ts

```
checked: boolean
```

Gets or sets the state switch.

Defaults to `false`.

### offBackgroundColor [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#offbackgroundcolor)

ts

```
offBackgroundColor: Color
```

Gets or sets the off-state background color.

See [Color](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/class/Color).

### ...Inherited [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#inherited)

For additional inherited properties, refer to the [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/class/Switch).

## Events [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#events)

### checkedChange [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#checkedchange)

ts

```
on('checkedChange', (args: PropertyChangeData) => {
  const switch = args.object as Switch
  console.log('Switch checked:', args.value)
})
```

See [PropertyChangeData](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/interface/PropertyChangeData).

## Native component [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch\#native-component)

- Android: [`android.widget.Switch`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/Switch.html)
- iOS: [`UISwitch`](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiswitch)

Previous [‚ÜêSlider](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider)

Next [TabView‚Üí](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/tab-view)

On this page

1. ‚Üë Top
2. [Examples](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#examples)
1. [Styling a Switch](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#styling-a-switch)
3. [Props](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#props)
1. [checked](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#checked)
2. [offBackgroundColor](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#offbackgroundcolor)
3. [...Inherited](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#inherited)
4. [Events](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#events)
1. [checkedChange](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#checkedchange)
5. [Native component](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch#native-component)

## Progress Component Guide
[**üöÄ 8.9 Released!** ‚Üí ‚ö°Ô∏è New Node-API Engine Preview, üì≤ ns widget ios, üíÖ Tailwind v4 and more...\\
Read Announcement‚Üí](https://blog.nativescript.org/nativescript-8-9-announcement)

Menu

  - [Label](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/label)
  - [ListPicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-picker)
  - [ListView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-view)

  - [Progress](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress)
  - [ScrollView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/scroll-view)
  - [SearchBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/search-bar)
  - [SegmentedBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/segmented-bar)
  - [Slider](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider)
  - [Switch](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch)
  - [TabView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/tab-view)
  - [TextField](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-field)
  - [TextView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-view)
  - [TimePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/time-picker)
  - [WebView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/web-view)

`<Progress>` is a UI component that shows a bar to indicate the progress of a task.

See also: [ActivityIndicator](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/activity-indicator).

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Progress.5112d167.png)

![](https://docs.nativescript.org/assets/Progress.da7075e2.png)

TypeScript
TypeScript
Angular
Angular
Vue.js
Vue
Svelte
Svelte
Solid
Solid
React
React

xml

```
<Progress value="75" />
```

html

```
<Progress value="75"></Progress>
```

tsx

```
export function Progress() {

  const [currentValue, setCurrentValue] = React.useState(0)
  setInterval(() => {
    setCurrentValue(currentValue + 10)
    if (currentValue > 101) setCurrentValue(0)
  }, 1000)

  return (
    <frame>
      <page style={styles.container}>
        <actionBar title="Progress"></actionBar>

        <gridLayout>

          <progress value={currentValue} />

        </gridLayout>
      </page>
    </frame>
  )
}
```

tsx

```
import { createSignal } from 'solid-js'

export const Progress = () => {
  const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0)
  setInterval(() => {
    setCount(count() + 1)
    if (count() === 101) setCount(0)
  }, 100)
  return (
    <>
      <actionbar title="Progress">
      </actionbar>
      <gridlayout>
        <progress value={count()}></progress>
      </gridlayout>
    </>
  )
}
```

svelte

```
<script lang="ts">
  let currentValue = 0
  setInterval(() => {
    currentValue++
    if (currentValue === 101) currentValue = 0
  }, 100)
</script>

<page>
  <actionBar title="Progress">
  </actionBar>

  <gridLayout width="100%">
    <progress bind:value={currentValue}></progress>
  </gridLayout>
</page>
```

vue

```
<script lang="ts" setup>
  import { ref } from 'vue'

  const currentValue = ref(0);
  setInterval( () =>{
    currentValue.value ++;
    if(currentValue.value === 101)
      currentValue.value = 0;
  }, 100);
</script>

<template>
  <Page>
    <GridLayout>
      <Progress :value="currentValue"></Progress>
    </GridLayout>
  </Page>
</template>
```

## Example [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress\#example)

### Styling the Progress bar [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress\#styling-the-progress-bar)

To style the Progress bar, set the `backgroundColor` and `color`.

The `backgroundColor` will be applied to the track, and the `color` will be applied to the bar itself.

xml

```
<Progress
  value="75"
  backgroundColor="#fff"
  color="#000"
/>
```

## Props [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress\#props)

### value [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress\#value)

ts

```
value: number
```

Gets or sets the current value of the progress bar.

Must be within the range of 0 to [maxValue](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#maxValue).

### maxValue [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress\#maxValue)

ts

```
maxValue: number
```

Gets or sets the maximum value of the progress bar.

Defaults to: `100`.

### ...Inherited [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress\#inherited)

For additional inherited properties, refer to the [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/class/Progress)

## Native component [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress\#native-component)

- Android: [`android.widget.ProgressBar` (indeterminate = false)](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/ProgressBar.html)
- iOS: [`UIProgressView`](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiprogressview)

Previous [‚ÜêPlaceholder](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder)

Next [ScrollView‚Üí](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/scroll-view)

2. [Example](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#example)
1. [Styling the Progress bar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#styling-the-progress-bar)
3. [Props](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#props)
1. [value](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#value)
2. [maxValue](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#maxValue)
3. [...Inherited](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#inherited)
4. [Native component](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress#native-component)

Updating a NativeScript app is usually a quick process if done regularly. The following guides aim to document the general update steps, highlighting breaking changes (if any) when updating between specific versions.

## Update guides [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/updating/\#update-guides)

- [Updating to latest](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/updating/to-latest)
- More soon...

## Updating to a tagged version [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/updating/\#updating-to-a-tagged-version)

To try upcoming features that have not been release yet, you can install the `next` tag of the CLI (built from the latest commit in the [NativeScript CLI repository](https://github.com/NativeScript/nativescript-cli/commits/main)) via:

bash

```
npm install -g nativescript@next
```

You can also pass a tag to the `ns update` command.

For example, to try all the latest features that have not made it into a stable release yet, you can run:

bash

```
ns update next
```

Previous [‚ÜêTesting](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/testing)

Next [To Latest‚Üí](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/updating/to-latest)

On this page

1. ‚Üë Top
2. [Update guides](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/updating/#update-guides)
3. [Updating to a tagged version](https://docs.nativescript.org/guide/updating/#updating-to-a-tagged-version)

`ApplicationSettings` allows you to store and retrieve data from the device local storage via getters and setters for storing and retrieving different data types. Use the appropriate setter to avoid errors.

## How to use ApplicationSettings [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#how-to-use-applicationsettings)

### Store a string value [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#store-a-string-value)

To store a string value, use the [setString](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings#setstring) method:

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.setString('username', 'Wolfgang')
```

TIP

You can use this method with the `JSON.stringify()` (as shown in the `saveObjectAsString` method in the StackBlitz demo app at the link above) to store an object or an array as a string. Then, use `JSON.parse()` to convert the result of [getString()](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings#getstring) back to the object or array.

### Store a boolean value [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#store-a-boolean-value)

To store a boolean value, call the [setBoolean](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings#setboolean) method passing the key as the first argument and the value as second argument.

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.setBoolean('isTurnedOn', true)
```

### Store a numeric value [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#store-a-numeric-value)

To store a number, use the [setNumber()](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings#setnumber) method:

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.setNumber('locationX', 54.321)
```

## ApplicationSettings API [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#applicationsettings-api)

### setString() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#setstring)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.setString(key: string, value: string)
```

Stores a string value for the specified key.

* * *

### getString() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#getstring)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.getString(key: string, deafaultValue?: string)
```

Gets a value (if existing) for a key as a `String` object. A default value can be provided in case there is no existing value.

* * *

### setNumber() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#setnumber)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.setNumber(key: string, value: number)
```

Sets a `Number` object for a key.

* * *

### getNumber() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#getnumber)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.getNumber(key: string, deafaultValue?: number)
```

Gets a value (if existing) for a key as a `Number` object. A default value can be provided in case the value does not exist.

* * *

### setBoolean() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#setboolean)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.setBoolean(key: string, value: boolean)
```

Sets a `boolean` for a key.

* * *

### getBoolean() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#getboolean)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.getBoolean(key: string, deafaultValue?: boolean)
```

Gets a value (if existing) for a key as a `boolean`. A default value can be provided in case the value does not exist.value.

* * *

### remove() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#remove)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.remove(key: string)
```

Removes the key and its value from the device storage.

* * *

### clear() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#clear)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.clear()
```

Removes all values from the device storage.

* * *

### getAllKeys() [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#getallkeys)

ts

```
ApplicationSettings.getAllKeys(): Array<string>
```

Returns an array of all stored keys or an empty array if no keys exist in the device storage.

* * *

## API Reference(s) [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#api-reference-s)

- [ApplicationSettings](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/namespace/ApplicationSettings) module

## Native Component [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/core/application-settings\#native-component)

- `Android`: [SharedPreferences](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/SharedPreferences)
- `iOS`: [NSUserDefaults](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/foundation/nsuserdefaults)

## Useful tips [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#useful-tips)

### Deleting XCode DerivedData [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#deleting-xcode-deriveddata)

XCode caches build data inside a folder called `DerivedData` \- occasionally it can get corrupted due to a bad build, and subsequent builds can fail until the cached artifacts are cleared.

[Learn more in this guide to delete DerivedData](https://programmingwithswift.com/delete-derived-data-xcode/)

### Stopping the ADB server [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#stopping-the-adb-server)

adb can sometimes get stuck in an unresponsive state. In these cases, you can force restart the adb server by running:

bash

```
adb kill-server
```

## Common issues [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#common-issues)

### Cocoapods Environment setup: CocoaPods is not installed or is not configured properly [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#cocoapods-environment-setup-cocoapods-is-not-installed-or-is-not-configured-properly)

bash

```
WARNING: CocoaPods is not installed or is not configured properly.
 You will not be able to build your projects for iOS if they contain plugin with CocoaPod file.
To be able to build such projects, verify that you have installed CocoaPods (sudo gem install cocoapods).
```

Cocoapods can be installed in system directories or via [homebrew](https://brew.sh/). Depending on which your system may already have them setup can lead to common issues in how Cocoapods are detected.

You can try running the following safely:

bash

```
pod cache clean -all
pod deintegrate
rm -rf "${HOME}/Library/Caches/CocoaPods"

brew install cocoapods
```

You can then confirm your Cocoapods installed properly and have the version you expect by running:

bash

```
pod --version
```

You could then try running `ns doctor` again.

### XCode 14: xcodebuild failed with exit code 65 [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#xcode-14-xcodebuild-failed-with-exit-code-65)

bash

```
error: Signing for "XXX-YYY" requires a development team.
Select a development team in the Signing & Capabilities editor. (in target 'XXX-YYY' from project 'Pods')

<...>
note: Run script build phase 'NativeScript PreBuild' will be run during every build because the option to
run the script phase "Based on dependency analysis" is unchecked. (in target 'XXX' from project 'XXX')
<...>

** BUILD FAILED **

Unable to apply changes on device: XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXX.
Error is: Command xcodebuild failed with exit code 65.
```

üü† Possible Solution

The most likely issue is a missing `DEVELOPMENT_TEAM` for some Pods. The workaround is to put the following in `App_Resources/iOS/Podfile` (create one if your project doesn't have it already):

ruby

```
post_install do |installer|
  installer.pods_project.targets.each do |target|
    target.build_configurations.each do |config|
      # either set the DEVELOPMENT_TEAM explicitly
      config.build_settings['DEVELOPMENT_TEAM'] = '<TEAM_ID>'
      # or disable code signing
      config.build_settings['CODE_SIGNING_ALLOWED'] = 'NO'
    end
  end
end
```

Replacing `<TEAM_ID>` with your actual team id.

### CocoaPods could not find compatible versions for pod [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#cocoapods-could-not-find-compatible-versions-for-pod)

```
CocoaPods could not find compatible versions for pod "SDWebImage":
  In Podfile:
    SDWebImage (~> 5.13.2)
```

üü¢ Common Solution

CocoaPods are like npm packages but for iOS libraries (it‚Äôs their own npm registry if you will). Your local Cocoapods cache (usually located in `~/.cocoapods`) keeps a Spec list reference that can become outdated and needs to be manually updated with the following command:

bash

```
pod repo update
```

In case this doesn't resolve the issue, you can often [delete the XCode DerivedData](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting#delete-xcode-deriveddata).

### CocoaPods could not find compatible versions for pod - higher minimum deployment target [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#cocoapods-could-not-find-compatible-versions-for-pod-higher-minimum-deployment-target)

```
[!] CocoaPods could not find compatible versions for pod "FBSDKCoreKit":
  In Podfile:
    FBSDKCoreKit (~> 13.1.0)

Specs satisfying the `FBSDKCoreKit (~> 13.1.0)` dependency were found, but they required a higher minimum deployment target.
```

üü¢ Common Solution

Increase the `IPHONEOS_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET` in your `App_Resources/iOS/build.xcconfig`:

bash

```
IPHONEOS_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET = 13.0;
```

The above will increase the deployment target of the app, however you might also need to increase the deployment target of CocoaPods too. Put the following in your `App_Resources/iOS/Podfile` (create it if you don't have one):

ruby

```
platform :ios, '13.0'

post_install do |installer|
  installer.pods_project.targets.each do |target|
    target.build_configurations.each do |config|
      config.build_settings['IPHONEOS_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET'] = '13.0'
    end
  end
end
```

In this example we are setting it to `13.0` \- change it to a version that makes sense for your project. Some libraries will require higher targets, so in most cases find the highest required target, and use that as your deployment target. Make sure to match both `build.xcconfig` and `Podfile` versions.

In case this doesn't resolve the issue, you can often [delete the XCode DerivedData](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting#deleting-xcode-deriveddata).

### dyld: Symbol not found [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#dyld-symbol-not-found)

```
dyld: Symbol not found: __ZNSt3__115basic_stringbufIcNS_11char_traitsIcEENS_9allocatorIcEEE3strERKNS_12basic_stringIcS2_S4_EE
  Referenced from: /path/to/app/platforms/ios/internal/metadata-generator-x86_64/bin/./objc-metadata-generator (which was built for Mac OS X 12.0)
  Expected in: /usr/lib/libc++.1.dylib
```

üü† Possible Solution

This can happen when a library uses a symbol not avaialble in the current deployment target.

Increase the `IPHONEOS_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET` in your `App_Resources/iOS/build.xcconfig`:

bash

```
IPHONEOS_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET = 13.0;
```

The above will increase the deployment target of the app, however you might also need to increase the deployment target of CocoaPods too. Put the following in your `App_Resources/iOS/Podfile` (create it if you don't have one):

ruby

```
platform :ios, '13.0'

post_install do |installer|
  installer.pods_project.targets.each do |target|
    target.build_configurations.each do |config|
      config.build_settings['IPHONEOS_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET'] = '13.0'
    end
  end
end
```

In this example we are setting it to `13.0` \- change it to a version that makes sense for your project. Some libraries will require higher targets, so in most cases find the highest required target, and use that as your deployment target. Make sure to match both `build.xcconfig` and `Podfile` versions.

In case this doesn't resolve the issue, you can often [delete the XCode DerivedData](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting#deleting-xcode-deriveddata).

### Unable to apply changes on device [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#unable-to-apply-changes-on-device)

```
Installing on device XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXX...
Unable to apply changes on device: XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXX.
Error is: Failed to install /path/to/appname/platforms/ios/build/Debug-iphoneos/appname.ipa
on device with identifier XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXX. Error is: Could not install application.
```

üü† Possible Solution

Open the project in XCode ( `platforms/ios/<appname>.xcworkspace`) and then select the project name in the left file tree. You should see **General**, **Signing & Capabilities** and other tabs in the middle. Select your device as the run target in the top bar, then select **Signing & Capabilities** and select an appropriate team, and if necessary press the **Register Device** button in the Profiles list.

Once the device is registered, you can exit XCode, and running the app from the NativeScript CLI should work as expected.

### EMFILE: too many open files 'FILE\_PATH' [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#emfile-too-many-open-files-file-path)

```
Webpack compilation complete. Watching for file changes.
Watchpack Error (watcher): Error: EMFILE: too many open files 'FILE_PATH'
Watchpack Error (watcher): Error: EMFILE: too many open files 'FILE_PATH'
Watchpack Error (watcher): Error: EMFILE: too many open files 'FILE_PATH' <-- This repeats many times
```

üü† Possible Solution

Add the following lines to your shell profile, usually `~/.zshrc`, or if you are using `bash` then `~/.bash_profile` or `~/.bashrc` config file:

bash

```
export NODE_OPTIONS="--max-old-space-size=4096"
```

Reload your shell (eg, `source ~/.zshrc`) or open a new terminal window and try running again.

**Note**: you can increase this number further, but keep in mind the maximum value depends on the available system memory.

### error TS2611: 'xxx' is defined as a property in class 'Y', but is overridden here in 'Z' as an accessor [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/troubleshooting\#error-ts2611-xxx-is-defined-as-a-property-in-class-y-but-is-overridden-here-in-z-as-an-accessor)

```
ERROR: node_modules/@nativescript/core/ui/proxy-view-container/index.d.ts:10:9
error TS2611: 'ios' is defined as a property in class 'LayoutBase',
but is overridden here in 'ProxyViewContainer' as an accessor.

10 get ios(): any;
~~~

node_modules/@nativescript/core/ui/proxy-view-container/index.d.ts:11:9
error TS2611: 'android' is defined as a property in class 'LayoutBase',
but is overridden here in 'ProxyViewContainer' as an accessor.

11 get android(): any;
```

üü¢ Common Solution

The above can be ignored by adding the following to your `tsconfig.json`:

json

```
"skipDefaultLibCheck": true,
"skipLibCheck": true,
```

## GridLayout Usage Guide
[**üöÄ 8.9 Released!** ‚Üí ‚ö°Ô∏è New Node-API Engine Preview, üì≤ ns widget ios, üíÖ Tailwind v4 and more...\\
Read Announcement‚Üí](https://blog.nativescript.org/nativescript-8-9-announcement)

Menu

- [Docs](https://docs.nativescript.org/)
- [Tutorials](https://docs.nativescript.org/tutorials/)
- [Preview](https://preview.nativescript.org/)
- [Snacks](https://docs.nativescript.org/snacks/)
- [Plugins](https://docs.nativescript.org/plugins/)
- [UI Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/)
- [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/)

- [Layout Containers](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#layout-containers)
  - [StackLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/stack-layout)
  - [GridLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout)
  - [RootLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/root-layout)
  - [FlexboxLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/flexbox-layout)
  - [WrapLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/wrap-layout)
  - [DockLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dock-layout)
  - [AbsoluteLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/absolute-layout)
- [Navigation Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#navigation-containers)
  - [Frame](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/frame)
  - [Page](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/page)
  - [ActionBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/action-bar)
- [Dialogs](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs)
  - [Alert](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#alert)
  - [Action](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#action)
  - [Confirm](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#confirm)
  - [Prompt](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#prompt)
  - [Login](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/dialogs#login)
- [Components](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/#components)
  - [ActivityIndicator](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/activity-indicator)
  - [Button](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/button)
  - [DatePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/date-picker)
  - [HtmlView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/html-view)
  - [Image](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/image)
  - [Label](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/label)
  - [ListPicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-picker)
  - [ListView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/list-view)
  - [Placeholder](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/placeholder)
  - [Progress](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/progress)
  - [ScrollView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/scroll-view)
  - [SearchBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/search-bar)
  - [SegmentedBar](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/segmented-bar)
  - [Slider](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/slider)
  - [Switch](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/switch)
  - [TabView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/tab-view)
  - [TextField](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-field)
  - [TextView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/text-view)
  - [TimePicker](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/time-picker)
  - [WebView](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/web-view)

The grid consists of rows, columns, and cells. A cell can span one or more rows and one or more columns. It can contain multiple child elements which can span over multiple rows and columns, and even overlap each other.

By default, `<GridLayout>` has one column and one row. You can add columns and rows by configuring the `columns` and the `rows` properties. In these properties, you need to set the number of columns and rows and their width and height. You set the number of columns by listing their widths, separated by a comma. You set the number of rows by listing their heights, separated by a comma.

You can set a fixed size for column width and row height or you can create them in a responsive manner:

- **An absolute number:** Indicates a fixed size.
- **auto:** Makes the column as wide as its widest child or makes the row as tall as its tallest child.
- **\*:** Takes as much space as available after filling all auto and fixed size columns or rows.

## Examples [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#examples)

### GridLayout with fixed sizing [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#gridlayout-with-fixed-sizing)

The following example creates a simple 2-by-2 grid with fixed column widths and row heights.

xml

```
<GridLayout columns="115, 115" rows="115, 115">
  <Label text="0,0" row="0" col="0" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
  <Label text="0,1" row="0" col="1" backgroundColor="#075B88" />
  <Label text="1,0" row="1" col="0" backgroundColor="#1089CA" />
  <Label text="1,1" row="1" col="1" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
</GridLayout>
```

![](https://art.nativescript.org/layouts/grid_layout.svg)

### GridLayout with star sizing [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#gridlayout-with-star-sizing)

The following example creates a grid with responsive design, where space is allotted proportionally to child elements.

xml

```
<GridLayout columns="*, 2*" rows="2*, 3*" backgroundColor="#3c495e">
  <Label text="0,0" row="0" col="0" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
  <Label text="0,1" row="0" col="1" backgroundColor="#075B88" />
  <Label text="1,0" row="1" col="0" backgroundColor="#1089CA" />
  <Label text="1,1" row="1" col="1" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
</GridLayout>
```

![](https://art.nativescript.org/layouts/grid_layout_star_sizing.svg)

### GridLayout with fixed and auto sizing [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#gridlayout-with-fixed-and-auto-sizing)

The following example create a grid with one auto-sized column and one column with fixed size. Rows have a fixed height.

xml

```
<GridLayout columns="80, auto" rows="80, 80" backgroundColor="#3c495e">
  <Label text="0,0" row="0" col="0" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
  <Label text="0,1" row="0" col="1" backgroundColor="#075B88" />
  <Label text="1,0" row="1" col="0" backgroundColor="#1089CA" />
  <Label text="1,1" row="1" col="1" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
</GridLayout>
```

![](https://art.nativescript.org/layouts/grid_layout_fixed_auto.svg)

### GridLayout with mixed sizing and merged cells [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#gridlayout-with-mixed-sizing-and-merged-cells)

The following example creates a complex grid with responsive design, mixed width and height settings, and some merged cells.

xml

```
<GridLayout columns="40, auto, *" rows="40, auto, *" backgroundColor="#3c495e">
  <Label text="0,0" row="0" col="0" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
  <Label text="0,1" row="0" col="1" colSpan="2" backgroundColor="#075B88" />
  <Label text="1,0" row="1" col="0" rowSpan="2" backgroundColor="#1089CA" />
  <Label text="1,1" row="1" col="1" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
  <Label text="1,2" row="1" col="2" backgroundColor="#1089CA" />
  <Label text="2,1" row="2" col="1" backgroundColor="#075B88" />
  <Label text="2,2" row="2" col="2" backgroundColor="#43B3F4" />
</GridLayout>
```

![](https://art.nativescript.org/layouts/grid_layout_complex.svg)

## Props [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#props)

### columns [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#grid-columns)

ts

```
columns: string // eg. *, 50, auto
```

A string value representing column widths delimited with commas.

Valid values: an absolute number, `auto`, or `*`:

- A number indicates an absolute column width.
- `auto` makes the column as wide as its widest child.
- `*` makes the column occupy all available horizontal space. The space is proportionally divided over all star-sized columns. You can set values such as `3*` and `5*` to indicate a ratio of 3:5 in sizes.

### rows [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#grid-rows)

ts

```
rows: string // eg. *, 50, auto
```

A string value representing row heights delimited with commas.

Valid values: an absolute number, `auto`, or `*`:

- A number indicates an absolute row height.
- `auto` makes the row as tall as its tallest child.
- `*` makes the row occupy all available vertical space. The space is proportionally divided over all star-sized rows. You can set values such as `3*` and `5*` to indicate a ratio of 3:5 in sizes.

### ...Inherited [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#inherited)

Additional inherited properties not shown. Refer to the [API Reference](https://docs.nativescript.org/api/class/GridLayout).

## Children props [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#children-props)

When an element is a direct child of `<GridLayout>`, these properties are accounted for:

### row [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#row)

ts

```
row: number
```

The row for the element.

The rows are 0-indexed, so the first row is indicated by `0`.

### col [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#col)

ts

```
col: number
```

The column for the element.

The columns are 0-indexed, so the first column is indicated by `0`.

### rowSpan [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#rowspan)

ts

```
rowSpan: number
```

The number of rows for the element to span across.

### colSpan [‚Äã](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/grid-layout\#colspan)

ts

```
colSpan: number
```

The number of columns for the element to span across.

Previous [‚ÜêStackLayout](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/stack-layout)

Next [RootLayout‚Üí](https://docs.nativescript.org/ui/root-layout)
